interpretation_summary: The replication executed smoothly after minor code fixes (variable-name capitalization and year column detection). The final run reproduced the preregistered workflow: cleaned later-wave (2012–2018) GSS data, approximated the three latent classes via K-modes clustering (as pre-specified fallback when full LCA packages were unavailable), and performed a Welch t-test comparing evolution endorsement between Post-Secular and Traditional respondents. Results show a very large negative gap (27.6 % vs 83.4 %; Δ = -55.8 pp; t = -27.6, p < 0.0001). This replicates the directional expectation that Post-Seculars are less likely to accept evolution, and the finding is strongly significant, albeit with a far larger magnitude than the ~3 pp difference reported in the original 2006-2010 sample. Overall, the replication adhered closely to the plan and provides substantive support for the focal claim on an extended, non-overlapping dataset.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: High alignment. The code followed the preregistered steps: (1) load identical GSS indicators, (2) listwise delete missing cases, (3) estimate three latent groups (K-modes fallback explicitly allowed), (4) label classes using Bible literalism & science-knowledge diagnostics, (5) conduct Welch t-test on the binary ‘evolved’ item, and (6) apply two-sided p<0.05 criterion and directional check.

deviations.issue_description: Latent class estimation used K-modes clustering rather than full latent class analysis because latentpy was unavailable.
deviations.impact: Moderate: Class assignment could differ from true LCA, but clear separation in evolution endorsement suggests substantive validity; direction and significance unaffected.

deviations.issue_description: No survey weights applied in the t-test (mirrors prereg plan but differs from possible best practice).
deviations.impact: Low: May change absolute percentages slightly but unlikely to flip direction or significance given huge effect size.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Respondents in the Post-Secular class will be less likely than respondents in the Traditional class to state that humans evolved from other animals.
results_comparison.original_results: Only 3 % of Post-Secular respondents (vs a substantially higher share of Traditional respondents) endorsed evolution; difference reported as statistically significant (p < 0.05, two-tailed). Precise Traditional percentage not stated, but direction negative (Post-Secular < Traditional).
results_comparison.replication_results: Post-Secular mean endorsement = 0.276 (27.6 %); Traditional = 0.834 (83.4 %); mean difference = -0.558; Welch t = -27.606; p < 0.0001 (N_Post-Secular = 1328, N_Traditional = 541).
results_comparison.overall_answer: Yes – the replication satisfies preregistered criteria (negative direction and p < 0.05). Effect magnitude is much larger than originally reported, but this strengthens, rather than weakens, support for the claim.

replication_report: Replication successful: Post-Secular respondents in later GSS waves were dramatically less likely (-55.8 pp) than Traditional respondents to affirm human evolution, confirming the hypothesised negative relationship with very strong statistical evidence (p < 0.001).

failure_handling.suggestions: Maintain defensive data-loading code that automatically switches to pyreadstat when pandas cannot read older Stata versions.
Consider re-running with a true latent class analysis package (e.g., poLCA in R or scikit-mix) to verify that clustering approximation did not distort class boundaries.

notes: Magnitude discrepancy could stem from period effects (2012-2018 vs 2006-2010) or class-assignment approximations. Future work might replicate on the original waves with the same Python pipeline to isolate methodological vs temporal factors, and incorporate survey weights or logistic regression for robustness.
